title: How can I know response Content-Type?
Add append option for setting response headers.
body:
By default both express and node opt replace any header you set which makes it somewhat inconvenient when you need to append a header instead of replace one. A third parameter to `res.set` now controls whether or not the header is set or appended.

The default behavior remains the same as before (so all existing code works as usual), and the appropriate tests have been added.

One example where this behavior might be desirable is when setting cookies. You can do things like:

``` javascript
res.set('Cookie', 'foo=bar', true);
```

and _NOT_ interfere with anyone else who has happened to also set a cookie for the response.

title: .use path akwardly matches suffixes
body:
If I bind a handler by `.use('/intern',intern_handler)`, it matches any 'path' derived from `/intern`, like `/intern` itself, and for example `/intern/account`. 

However, this handler triggers on `/intern.html` too. 

The documentation states 'path can be a string representing a path', which gives the expectation of usual path-like logic. In the example above, it seems to be rather a prefix matching.

However, `/internals` does NOT trigger this handler. This contradicts prefix matching either.

So what is the rationale behind .use path matching? Without a clear specification, I would consider this behaviour a bug.

title: Release 4.11
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.11.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add `res.append` to append headers #2455
- [x] Deprecate `app.param(fn)` #2429
- [x] Deprecate `app.param(':name', fn)`, where `':name'` has the leading colon #2430 
- [x] Deprecate `req.param()` #2440
- [x] Fix `OPTIONS` responses to include the `HEAD` method property #2459
- [x] Match routes iteratively to prevent stack overflows #2412

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:

``` bash
$ npm install strongloop/express#4.11
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: Remove express.static
body:
I haven't seen much discussion to if we are actually going to remove `static` from `express@5`.

(People can always still require `serve-static`.)

Basically it doesn't make much sense to have these things in express core, imo.

We'll build a better CLI generator for people who want this stuff easy.

title: route handlers: performance bottleneck
body:
Is there something already being done or can be done about the array used as the data structure for storing route handlers as specified in this blog - http://techblog.netflix.com/2014/11/nodejs-in-flames.html
as part of the phased router improvements @bajtos ?

title: express 4.10.2 issue with sinon fake timers
body:
When calling Sinon.JS's `useFakeTimers` with the most recent version of Express, requests sent to the app aren't answered.

This is caused by the commit titled "Correctly invoke async router callback asynchronously", which changed line 186 of `lib/router/index.js` from `return done(layerError)` to `setImmediate(done, layerError)`.

When using fake timers, functions run using `setImmediate` don't execute until one explicitly ticks forward the clock.

It could be argued this isn't really a problem with Express, and rather the solution is to be sure to tick whenever one issues a request to the app. However, it's not entirely clear to me how this could be done, since one would have to know when Express got to that `setImmediate` call and only then tick. Further, even if it is possible, it's doubtful many existing tests do this, meaning this breaks a lot of existing code.

Presumably this is also a problem with any other framework that manipulates `setImmediate`, not just Sinon.

title: Parameters matching/Update path-to-regexp?
body:
Hi,

I've noticed something weird about named parameters in routes. In our app, we use a route similar to this one:

``` js
app.get('/concerts/:id*/videos', function (req, res) {});
```

where the id of a concert is a string formatted like that:

``` js
'yyyy/mm/dd/venue/artist'
```

Now the problem is, if we hit that route:

``` js
'/concerts/2014/11/21/venue/artist/videos'
```

the field `req.params.id` isn't populated with the value `'2014/11/21/venue/artist'` as expected, it only contains the value `'2014'`.

I was wondering if this is the intended behaviour or if this is a bug? I tried to update path-to-regexp from `0.1.3` to its latest version and then everything _seemed_ to work just the way I though it would work.

title: the same file has different ETag on two servers?
body:
My webapp serves some static files, like:

``` js
app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));
```

And it is deployed on two different servers (192.168.1.1 and 192.168.1.2).
When I request one static file, they respond the same file with different ETags.

```
curl -I http://192.168.1.1/webapp/img/1_1.png
ETag: "3368-1416384949000"
```

```
curl -I http://192.168.1.2/webapp/img/1_1.png
ETag: "3368-1414576453000"
```

So I check the file "1_1.png" respectively with md5sum, they all are:

md5sum 1_1.png
bf0d5bf5c87562d1bb668b8372550165  1_1.png

title: release 4.10.2 breaks compatibility with node 0.8.x
body: setImmediate is undefined. consider using https://www.npmjs.org/package/setimmediate to shim the implementation.

title: Callback to router.param listener function should be last argument
Deprecate req.param()
body:
Because it is better to make it obvious where you are getting the parameters from: `req.params`, `req.body`, or  `req.query`.

Keeping it will encourage developers to use it, which can potentially cause hard to debug or confusing issues.

Also, `req.param()` is a utility function, which should be at the application level, not in the framework.

title: How to dispatch route ?
body: Is it possible to dispatch some certain route programmatically like, `app.dispatch('get', '/foo', { params, querystrign ... }` ?

title: Better route filter and group routes
Add tracing capabilities to Express
body:
Hi Express team,

To follow the discussion posted in the #2191 issue, I send you a proposal to implement tracing support in Express. Let me know if it matches your requirements. It is inspired by Koa Trace.

**Goal**

We want to allow to trace the response life-cycle. The tracing should support any tracing technology. 

**Implementation**
- Add a `tracers` array at the application level.
- Add an `instrument` function on the application prototype to add a tracer to the tracer list.
- Add a `dispatch` function on the application prototype to activate all set tracers.
- Add a `trace` on the response prototype to run tracers with current context and given event as arguments. 
- Add tracing tests.
- Add tracing example.

```
router.use helmet.csp(config.server.csp)

app.use '/', router
app.use express.static(...)
```

The images still have the helmet CSP headers, while the docs say "A router is an isolated instance of middleware and routes."?

title: Support custom router
Deprecate app.param(name, fn) where name starts with a colon
body: Right now, `app.param(':id', fn)` is equivalent to `app.param('id', fn)`, which I believe is to be able to make the name look like it's the same syntax as in paths. This seems redundant and adds unnecessary complexity, and would be odd if there would someday be a way to use RFC 6570 for URLs.

title: Deprecate app.param(fn)
body: This is a discussion for the deprecation of the `app.param(fn)` signature. To me, it solves a problem that doesn't exist. I would like to hear arguments to keep it around, hopefully with a use-case it actually solves, before it gets deprecated.

title: Calling next() without a callback causes an error
body:
Hi Guys,

I have an issue where I have two routes that utilize the same controller function:

``` js
app.route('route1').post(callback1);
app.route('route2').post(callback1, callback2);
```

As you can see on route1 consists of just a single callback function,  and route2 contains a chain of two callbacks.

Callback1 returns a response on the 'res' object and calls next(), callback2 does nothing on the res object, it primarily reads some data from req and does some processing.

So route2 works fine, however route1 causes the 'Error: can set headers...' primarily because there is no callback from calling next().

Is this expected behaviour or there is a graceful way to handle this? As in just silently fail if there is no callback in the chain?

title: Optional custom json replacer/spaces per response
body:
In some cases it is useful to be able to overwrite the json replacer at response level, in the end it is something related to the response.

This change also makes it possible to simply say: `res.jsonReplacer = null; res.json(data);` to prevent the jsonReplacer from kicking in.

title: Fix fqdn detection when stripping prefixes from routes
body:
A URL as a parameter (unescaped, so `://` shows) would cause too much of
the URL to be chopped, assuming the entire URL through the parameter was
a prefix to be maintained as the 'protocol and host' of the path.

title: Missing application/octet-stream header for .end()
body: When using `res.end(new Buffer())`, the Content-Type is unset. I think it should set the application/octet-stream mime type, as does the send method.

title: route() should handle 405 Method not allowed
Why do you avoid classes and prototype?
Recursive route matching can overflow stack
body:
re: express@4.10.0, I searched but could not find a similar issue

See simple demo here: https://gist.github.com/ahamid/4064dc457a80ced1ab29

After upgrading from express 3.x to 4.x, I noticed some behavior that was really hard to track down.  On some routes Express would throw `RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded`.  After some experimentation I found that changing routes of the style:

``` js
app.post("thepath", handler);
app.put("thepath", handler);
```

to

``` js
app.route("thepath").post(handler)
                     .put(handler);
```

superficially made the problem go away; I assumed it had something to do with mapping multiple verbs to the same path or handler.

It turns out though that the problem is simply that Express is matching routes recursively, not iteratively, so if you just happen to request a route that was mapped later instead of earlier you run the risk of the `RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded`.  Obviously this depends on the stack size for the node process, how many internal calls Express makes, and chiefly the number of routes you have, which will likely have to be in the thousands.  In my particular case I am exposing a large dataset on the file system via Express and registering 3 handlers each (1400 \* 3 = 4200) which turns out to be enough routes to overflow.

The behavior I would expect is that route matching is performed iteratively, and should work irrespective of # of routes mapped.

The questions here then are:
1) are my assumptions correct about Express route matching implementation
2) is this actually a problem that Express is interested in solving, or is the answer "no. don't do that (map thousands of routes)" - in that case I would humbly request a note about implementation in the docs.

title: serv-static stops when loading many images from iphone mobile safari.
body:
I use serv-static and put one html and some images which will load from the html.
I connect this page from my iphone through LAN.
Mobile safari loading progress bar is stop and some image file is not loaded.

This issue doesn't occur in chrome on iOS, safari on Mac.

First I think this is safari issue and is not express issue.
But after my many investigation (eliminating application specific logic and search reproducible occurring condition), I think this is latter.

I found that logic flow which close file reading stream before sending file completion.
because of on-finish module implementation, if response.socket is null, it occur.
I print log about response.socket in SendStream.stream() and in case image file not loaded, it was null.

I tried to modify this code section. and issue is solved.

I report detail of this issue at this repository.
This can reproduce issue and run my patch.
https://github.com/omochi/express-serv-static-issue

I think that this stackoverflow is related to this issue.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26352839/linkedin-dustjs-on-node-express-ios-safari

title: Deprecated should only log once
body:
We're seeing a lot of

```
express deprecated res.send(status, body): Use res.status(status).send(body) instead at node_modules/toobusy-middleware/index.js:76:13
```

in our logs. It'd be great if express would only log this once, and state something like 'logging of this deprecation warning is now turned off' to avoid filling the logs with nothing but deprecated warnings.

Thanks!

title: Router: Cannot use literal characters \] and \) in Regex
Use <List> as array in Middleware
body:
Hello. I have an application that uses a model where there is a Catalog of items and a model for Collections (which are, basically, categories).
I want to put these Collections on the navigation bar, but for that, I need to get an array of menu items from `middleware.js`. How do I set my list of Collections from a keystone list? I tried just using `locals.collections = Collections`, which is basically `keystone.list("Collection")`, but I can't get its attributes. It only appears on my dropdown menu as `[Object] [Object] Name Model`. How do I use `<List>` on middleware?

title: Failure parsing querystring from windows client
body:
Hi, 

I have a windows client which sends a query string url encoded but the character encoding is 
not utf-8. I did open an issue within [`Qs`](https://github.com/hapijs/qs/issues/43). Unfortunately they say it's none of their business, only utf-8 is supported. `querystring` does also not work.

Is this to be considered a bug or bad luck with my client?

regards
dieter

The example:

``` ruby

qs = require('qs')

describe 'Qs', ->

  describe '#parse', ->
    it 'parses ucs2 from windows', (done) ->
      expect(unescape('%f6%e4%fc%e1%20')).to.be.like('öäüá ')
      expect(qs.parse('a=%f6%e4%fc%e1%20')).to.be.like( {'a': 'öäüá '})
      done()
```

title: Corruption when sending XLSX files
body:
People have reported issues with using express to send XLSX files as binary (XLSX files are zip files).  Based on the fact that the generated files are valid (when written using fs.writeFileSync), the bug appears to come from Express.

@notatestuser found a workaround by passing the data through a base64 encoding (see https://github.com/SheetJS/js-xlsx/issues/122#issuecomment-57184405), but that is not ideal because it requires converting to and from base64.

What is the recommended way to send XLSX files as response with express? 

Related public reports:

https://github.com/SheetJS/js-xlsx/issues/122
https://github.com/SheetJS/js-xlsx/issues/104

title: Escaped path crashes `decode_param`
body:
A request with escaped characters e.g. `/p%E4%E4si%E4inen`, i.e. `/pääsiäinen` (Finnish for easter), causes `decode_param` in `lib/layer.js` to choke. Or rather `decodeURIComponent` throws a `URIError`,  but the effect is the same.

This is a seemingly simple issue to fix (normalise, i.e. `unescape` path), but I'm unsure whether the obvious solution is indeed the right one, and also I'm at a loss about at which stage the patch should be applied. Quite sure it should not be in `layer.js`, though. 

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a server having a route with a capture group

```
var app = require("express")();

app.get(/^\/(.*)/, function (req, res, next) {
    res.
        header("Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8").
        status(200).
        send("Your path is:" + req.path)
    ;
});

app.listen(8080);
```

2) Request `http://localhost:8080/p%E4%E4si%E4inen`

Expected result: 

The request path echoed back to the browser

Actual result: 

```
TypeError: Failed to decode param 'p%E4%E4si%E4nen'
   at decode_param ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:147:15)
   at Layer.match ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:119:11)
   at Function.match_layer ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:288:16)
   at next ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:189:10)
   at expressInit ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/middleware/init.js:23:5)
   at Layer.handle [as handle_request] ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:76:5)
   at trim_prefix ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:270:13)
   at [...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:237:9
   at Function.proto.process_params ([...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:312:12)
   at [...]/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:228:12
```

Affected versions: discovered on 3.0.4, still present in 4.9.5

body:
Looking through the code and came across this little feature that is missing documentation:

``` js
req.param = function(name, defaultValue){
```

title: Allow immediate bail in Router
body: This allows one to bail out of a router immediately. This is useful if you check for some conditions inside a generic handler on the router (via `.use()`) first and then decide to skip the rest of that router's routes.

title: HTTP 2 support
body: Would be nice if Express had http 2 support on the roadmap, now that all major browsers support it in their current versions. So I am tossing it in here.

title: Redirect within Route
Empty string no longer a valid path for app.use in 4.9.1
Fix .use with empty string as path
body:
I don't know if this was ever intended, but prior to 4.9.1 (specifically, https://github.com/strongloop/express/commit/cf41a8f25434bde16ee8606ce12bb699ef9de39e#diff-5372f626ee15242f1e2c6eb31655b4faR168) an empty path "worked". I'm not saying it was a good practice, but the ensuing error message after upgrading to 4.9.1 is a bit unhelpful ("expected function but got Object").

So this 'restores' the tolerance for `app.use` with an empty string as the path. Alternatively, maybe checking if `fn` is an empty string and throwing a more specific error message would be better if the intention was to actually disallow it.

title: .sendFile broken behaviour from .sendfile
body:
Before `res.sendfile` was deprecated, this was correctly working:

``` js
res.sendfile('./public/routes/index.html');
```

Now with `res.sendFile()` this path is not anymore recognised as a valid absolute path. Is it really necessary to broke the behaviour of the path element? Can't it be backwards-compatible?

body:
This allows continuous integration platforms to retrieve and parse tests
results easily.

title: Truncated responses on Ubuntu 12.04.4
body:
I have an express.js server 3.17.1, on node v0.10.31, which is returning a large JSON object.  My [request.js](https://github.com/mikeal/request) based client was complaining that the JSON object couldn't be parsed with "unexpected end of input".

After some sleuthing, here's what I know:
- This problem does not appear to happen on OS/X, only on Ubuntu.
- I modified the server side to call JSON.stringify() and then send the string, so I know the server is writing 12,497,131 bytes.  The client is rather consistently receiving 163,648 bytes.
- If I try to connect to the server with CURL, I get the rather enigmatic error message: `curl: (18) transfer closed with 12333490 bytes remaining to read`

Anyone know what's going on here?  I'll see if I can whip up a quick gist that demonstrates the problem.

title: app.use() array argument fails on default mount path
body: When the mount path is not specified, app.use() fails if the first argument is an array.
